findings.title: Skill does not specify a license
findings.description: Skill manifest does not include a 'license' field. Specifying a license helps users understand usage terms.
findings.remediation: Add 'license' field to SKILL.md frontmatter (e.g., MIT, Apache-2.0)

findings.title: CREDENTIAL HARVESTING detected by YARA
findings.description: Detects potential exposure of sensitive information like API keys, passwords, tokens, and certificates: export TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY
findings.remediation: Review and remove credential harvesting pattern

findings.title: Missing License Declaration
findings.description: The skill does not specify a license in the YAML manifest. While not a direct security threat, this creates legal ambiguity about usage rights and redistribution, which can impact trust and adoption.
findings.remediation: Add a license field to the YAML frontmatter (e.g., 'license: MIT', 'license: Apache-2.0', or 'license: Proprietary').

metadata.overall_assessment: The 'captions' skill is a straightforward YouTube caption extraction tool that uses an external API (TranscriptAPI.com) via curl commands. The skill has a legitimate, well-documented purpose with no evidence of malicious intent. The primary security concerns are minor: missing optional metadata fields (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) and standard API key handling practices that could be improved with additional security guidance. No prompt injection, data exfiltration, command injection, or other critical threats were detected. The skill operates as described, making authenticated API calls to a third-party service to retrieve publicly available YouTube captions. The referenced files (YouTube.py, video.py) appear to be documentation artifacts rather than actual dependencies. Overall, this is a LOW-RISK skill suitable for use with minor documentation improvements recommended.
primary_threats: API key handling guidance could be strengthened
Referenced files not found in package

findings.title: Missing Compatibility Declaration
findings.description: The skill does not specify compatibility information (e.g., which Claude environments it works in). This is informational metadata that helps users understand where the skill can be used.
findings.remediation: Add a compatibility field to the YAML frontmatter (e.g., 'compatibility: Works in Claude.ai, Claude Code, API').

findings.title: Missing allowed-tools Declaration
findings.description: The skill does not specify allowed-tools in the YAML manifest. This is an optional field per the agent skills spec, but declaring it helps users understand which agent tools the skill requires (Bash for curl commands in this case).
findings.remediation: Add 'allowed-tools: [Bash]' to the YAML frontmatter to document that this skill uses Bash commands for API calls.

findings.title: Referenced Files Not Found in Package
findings.description: The instructions reference 'YouTube.py' and 'video.py' files that are not included in the skill package. These appear to be documentation artifacts or broken references rather than actual dependencies, but could cause confusion.
findings.snippet: Files referenced in instructions: YouTube.py, video.py (both not found)
findings.remediation: Remove references to YouTube.py and video.py from the instructions if they are not part of the skill package, or include these files if they are intended to be present.

findings.title: API Key Exposure Risk via Environment Variable
findings.description: The skill requires storing the TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY in ~/.zshenv, which is a shell configuration file that may be readable by other processes or accidentally committed to version control. While environment variables are a standard practice, the instructions could emphasize security best practices.
findings.remediation: Add a security note warning users to: (1) Never commit ~/.zshenv to version control, (2) Ensure proper file permissions (chmod 600 ~/.zshenv), (3) Consider using a secrets manager for production use. Also recommend adding ~/.zshenv to .gitignore.
